subject: RE: [junit] Junit question?
msgSnippet: To be more specific, if junit samples... is located in a hypothetical c: junit38 directory (i.e. c: junit38 junit samples ... , you should add c: junit38
messageBody:
To be more specific, if "junit\samples..." is located in a hypothetical
"c:\junit38" directory (i.e. c:\junit38\junit\samples\...", you should
add "c:\junit38" to the classpath. Do *not* add c:\junit38\junit, as
this will be one level too deep to be effective. The temptation to go
one level too deep in Java classpath settings is very strong.

-----------------------------
Mike Silverstein
SilverMark, Inc.
The Object Testing Company
www.javatesting.com

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Manuel Amago [mailto:mamago@...]
> Sent: Friday, January 17, 2003 4:57 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: RE: [junit] Junit question?
>
>
> Have you noticed that the samples/AllTests.java classes are
> in the package junit.samples and should be run from the base
> directory (i.e. junit/samples/../..?
>
> Manuel Amago.
> mailto:mamago@...
>
>
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: simon_orchanian <simon_orchanian@...>
> > [mailto:simon_orchanian@...]
> > Sent: 17 January 2003 00:39
> > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > Subject: [junit] Junit question?
> >
> >
> > Hi,
> >
> > I just joined this group and am fairly new to Junit. I have
> > downloaded junit and set my classpath accordingly but cannot
> > get it to run the simple AllTests using the command given on
> > the Website. I always receive an error saying it cannot find
> > the class AllTests, yet it is there.
> >
> > Any help would be greatly appreciated.
> >
> > Thank you,
> > Simon
